conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful note and for staying engaged throughout the process.

At a high level, yes—we are still keeping our single remaining seat available in case a higher-priority candidate contacts School_C in a later round. Because conversations can shift late (students may be declined elsewhere and re-approach schools), we are not ready to finalize the seat yet.

What would need to change for us to move from “reserving the seat” to making an offer is essentially one of the following:
1) We reach a point where it becomes clear we are unlikely to receive any applications from higher-priority candidates in the remaining rounds, or
2) We reach the final stage of the process and must fill (or intentionally leave unfilled) our last seat.

I understand this uncertainty is difficult, and I appreciate your continued interest. I strongly encourage you to keep pursuing parallel options so you are not left without a placement. If our position changes, we will be able to act quickly.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_C’s true priority list. Higher-priority students are Student_B, Student_A, and Student_D. So the only realistically likely higher-priority applicant to approach School_C later is Student_B (and possibly Student_A/D only if rejected everywhere, which is less likely but possible). Because quota is 1 and we prefer holding the seat for higher-priority candidates, we should continue to delay rather than commit to Student_E. Student_E sent [TALK], so we respond with [TALK] and clarify what would change: receiving/confirming no higher-priority interest, or reaching a late-round cutoff. We should avoid giving confidential specifics about other applicants but can speak generally.
